messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:43): If I look for /<[a-z]+ [a-z]+="([^"]+)"[a-z][^= ]*/ in the subset of the 130K pages that have a URI whose MD5 starts with '8', then I find things like
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:43): <table width="100% align="center">
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:43): <a href="<div align="center">
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:43): <a href="pages/leaders.html"Leadership"">
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:43): <img src="http://cgi.knc.ne.jp/cgi/counter/counter.pl?USER=cci&URL=index.html"alt"=counter align="bottom" width="35" height="16" border="0">

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:44): <a href="http://www.myrope.com/"index.asp" target="_top">

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:44): and several more that are simply forgetting a closing '"'
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:46): Oops, I meant /<[a-z]+ [a-z]+="([^"]+)"[a-z][^= ]*"/
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (16:47): all of those are covered by banning " in attribute names, afaict

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:48): It would probably be much more useful if I looked for all the cases that hit the relevant parse error in the tokeniser, but that would take more effort than I want to bother with now
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (16:49): i think this is useful enough data for sending to the list
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:50): Given what I was searching for, I don't think it'd be possible to find anything that wouldn't be interpreted as a quote in an attribute name
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (16:52): good point :)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:10): hmm, getAttribute() returns the empty string instead of null in ie8 if the attribute is absent
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:17): Is that consistent with other browsers?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:18): wonders why his spec-processing script creates output saying "<aÔø?href="a">a<table><aÔø?href="b">b</table>x" with something funny in place of the spaces, only in that particular instance and nowhere else in the document
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (17:23): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: that's consistent with DOM, but not with the web.
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (17:23): Or is it other way around?
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (17:24): no, I got it right the first time around.
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (17:25): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: the classic yahoo mail at least used to depend on getAttribute("missing") returning null.
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:33): hmm, i think <input type=number value=""> should be valid html5
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:34): (haven't checked the spec but V.nu says it's invalid)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:37): they implemented getAttribute() per spec? classic...
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:38): i guess they went through the dom 2 core testsuite
b19bfcbd7b695025e49d546be54e168b (17:39): did they start throwing WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR too?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:40): dunno
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (17:40): not very unexpectedly, they made changes to quirks mode and ie7 mode too
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:41): which makes their claims about "not breaking the Web" a lot less convincing...
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:42): it does further the cause of making Trident near impossible to imitate
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (17:43): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: what do you mean by "above-dom"?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:43): a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d: I mean code that reads the DOM
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:43): It makes people's claims that IE would contain three independent frozen-in-time rendering engines incorrect
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:43): a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d: the SVG and MathML renderers
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:43): (and scripts that access the DOM, too)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:43): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, yes, that was me :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:44): guess I was ill informed
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:46): have I understood correctly that the IE8 CSS renderer shares the DOM impl. with the IE7 and IE5.5 modes?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:46): but the DOM impl changes some of its behavior conditionally?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:48): i think that's the case, yes
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:48): versioned APIs or something

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:48): Would <style>a[title]{color:green}</style><a title>example</a> be a way of testing that, given what 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 said about IE8 dropping attributes?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:49): probably or hasAttribute("title") maybe

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:51): http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc288472(VS.85).aspx - "The alt attribute is no longer displayed as the image tooltip when the browser is running in IE8 mode. Instead, the target of the longDesc attribute is used as the tooltip if present; otherwise, the title is displayed."
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:51): hadn't seen that before
1e4ee64444841994c72c2d5293d9734b (17:52): Given how much people mung up the content of the longdesc attribute, I have to wonder about the virtue of exposing it that way.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:53): is there a screenshot of the longdesc thing happening?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:53): Given how little people use longdesc, it doesn't matter too much what you do with it
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:54): wonders what it'll do on Wikipedia images
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:54): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, is MathML just verbose or is it not possible to get Math compact in XML/HTML markup?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (17:56): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: the latter

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:56): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: as far as I can tell, math requires lots of layout boxes, although CSS can have anonymous boxes, tweakable boxes practically have to be elements. that translates into very verbose markup
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:56): Does <tex>e^{i\pi}=2</tex> count as "XML/HTML markup"?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:57): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: at least it would take anonymous box generation to a whole new level...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:57): (I'm assuming here that we want a solution that integrates at least semi-sanely with a CSS formatter)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:58): At some level of abstraction <span>test test-test test&shy;test test</span> does complex anonymous-box-like stuff to separate and wrap words
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (17:58): http://www.w3.org/TR/mathml-for-css/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:58): (and I don't know what level of abstraction is the right one to look from)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:59): a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d: not sufficient for Musings
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (17:59): understood, but he assumes that the spec is unchanging
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (17:59): if, however, you assume that the spec can be fixed, then it no longer is an HTML5 problem.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:00): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, tweakable boxes could be ::foo
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:01): I'm assuming that in the near term fixing SVG and MathML as they are processed above the DOM should be out of scope for the WHATWG
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:01): I do think that the MathML 3 spec can still change, though
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:02): which reminds me that I should follow up on some of my comments on MathML 3

a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:03): opera's direction (last I heard) was to do mathml via css.  Whether they do so, or don't do so, and whether their doing so is sufficient for Musings is not a problem that the HTML5 working group needs to solve.
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:03): Preventing MathML from being styled via CSS would be bad.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:04): a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d: I agree on both counts
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:04): cool.  I see the HTML5's WG's job to get the markup into the DOM.  And that's as far as the job goes.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:04): but as it stands, presentational MathML has useful bits that can't be emulated with a generic XML tree and CSS3
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:04): then opera may have a problem with their approach.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:04): so I think Gecko's MathML code and MathPlayer will still be relevant

a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (18:06): if HTML5's HTML 5 deserialization produces the same result as HTML5's XHTML5 deserialization of equivalent documents (modulo syntax differences only), then the HTML5 working group's job is done.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:07): which is why I think part of the solution is already constrained more than Hixie's email suggested

1e4ee64444841994c72c2d5293d9734b (18:10): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I don't see IE8 doing anything with displaying longdesc in a tooltip, so I guess their documention is, as they say, 'preliminary'....
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:11): 1e4ee64444841994c72c2d5293d9734b: Do you know if they still display alt in the tooltip?
1e4ee64444841994c72c2d5293d9734b (18:12): They do not, from what I'm seeing in a quick test.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:14): sees that IE8 has added CSS printing support for widows and orphans, and thinks it is good that they are supporting broken families
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:15): didn't someone say that the IE7 engine was still used for printing?
1e4ee64444841994c72c2d5293d9734b (18:15): I think their release notes say it, but I'm not looking at them right this moment.
1e4ee64444841994c72c2d5293d9734b (18:16): finds the notes, and yes it's in the notes
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:17): hmm. not a total freeze of the IE7 CSS formatter then?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:19): It's still quite possible that they've only added to the IE8 CSS print formatter, but the current beta uses IE7 for printing
